title-group.article-title: Molecular Analysis of Cell Type-Specific Gene Expression Profile During Mouse Spermatogenesis by Laser Microdissection and qRT-PCR

article-meta.aff: 1VA St. Louis Health Care System, St. Louis, MO, USA
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis, MO, USA

author-notes.corresp: Kelle H. Moley, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Washington University, School of Medicine, 660 South Euclid Ave, Campus Box 8064, St. Louis, MO 63110, USA. Email: moleyk@wustl.edu

abstract.p: Laser microdissection (LMD) is a selective cell isolation technique that enables the separation of desired homogenous cell subpopulations from complex tissues such as the testes under direct microscopic visualization. The LMD accompanied by quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) represents an indispensable tool in quantifying messenger RNA (mRNA) expression among defined cell populations. Gene expression is temporally and spatially regulated at 3 sequential phases of mitotic, meiotic, and postmeiotic stages of spermatogenesis. The present study demonstrates a short modified LMD protocol based upon hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Stage-specific LMD success was validated by the use of mRNA profiling of “marker genes” which are conserved across species and are known to be differentially expressed during spermatogenesis. Magea4, Hspa2, Cox6b2, Tnp1, Prm1, and Prm2 are used to differentiate among the microdissected cell populations, namely spermatogonia (group I), spermatocytes (group II), round and condensing spermatids (group III), and elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV), respectively. The LMD combined with qRT-PCR is further extended to assess the cell stage-specific distribution of selected stress response genes such as Hsp90aa1, Gpx4, Ucp2, Sod1, and Sod2. The germ cell-specific mRNA profiles are suitably complemented by Western blot of the LMD samples, immunohistochemistry, and confocal localization of the corresponding proteins. The current study suggests that LMD can successfully isolate cell subpopulations from the complex tissues of the testes; and establish cell stage-specific basal expression patterns of selected stress response genes and proteins. It is our hypothesis that the baseline expression of stress response genes will differ by cell stage to create discrete stage-specific vulnerabilities to reproductive toxicants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The identification, isolation, and analysis of individual cell populations at the molecular level from complex and heterogeneous tissues have been a challenge for many years. Laser microdissection (LMD) has made a significant contribution toward cell separation 1 and thereby enabled the rapid and reliable isolation of specific cell types from complex tissues, while maintaining the integrity of DNA, RNA, and protein. However, LMD can be technically demanding. The varied LMD platforms, combined with the preceding and the subsequent downstream applications, each have the potential to introduce multiple variables that can either optimize or compromise the integrity of DNA, RNA, and proteins. The LMD was initially employed in cancer tissues 2 and successfully extended to study gene expression in several tissues 3 such as the complex epithelia of the kidney glomeruli, 4 neuronal subtypes, 5 and breast cancer. 6 Entire cross sections of rat seminiferous tubules were captured using the Arcturus PixCell II laser capture microdissection7 (Arcturus Engineering, Mountain View, California), to result in aggregate cellular signals from the complex cell population. The Arcturus manual PIXEL, the automated Arcturus AutoPix, and the Biorad Clonis are pure infrared (IR) systems which do not allow the capture of single cells. In a subsequent work, the Zeiss PALM laser catapulting LCM system was used to capture regional zones of the rat seminiferous epithelium known to be populated by the selected cell stages (basal, mid section, and luminal) rather than discrete germ cell populations. 8 However, the interwoven sertoli cell and germ cell contact would be expected to result in sertoli cell contamination. While the ultraviolet (UV) LMD systems (Leica LMD 6000, 7000, and 7500, the Zeiss PALM, and Molecular Machines CellCut) allow single cell dissection, 9 it would also greatly increase the time spent in LMD with the potential to compromise the integrity of RNA.

Spermatogenesis is a tightly regulated and complex biological process of cellular differentiation that results in the production of haploid male germ cells. The spermatogenic cycle is divided into 14 spermatogenic stages in the rat and 12 stages in mouse. The 12 stages of the mouse seminiferous epithelium are defined according to changes observed in the Golgi region of the spermatids and the preponderance of cell types in a particular developmental stage. 10 For the purposes of this study, the stages were grouped into early stages I to V, middle stages VI to VIII, and late stages IX to XII. In addition to morphology, the spermatogenic cells were further elucidated by the expression of stage and cell-specific marker genes. 11,12 Unlike other tissues, the migrating and differentiating male germ cells maintain cell-to-cell connection through cytoplasmic connections, and direct contact with the Sertoli cells via the interwoven cytoplasmic projections, thereby compromising efforts to investigate cell stage-specific nucleic acids and proteins. Consequently LMD promises to advance the understanding of spermatogenesis. 13 However, very few studies address the isolation of individual male germ cells based on cell-specific marker genes using LMD, 14 and there are no published reports, or LMD methodology for the characterization of germ cell-specific proteins.

Therefore, the primary aim of this study was to optimize a short LMD protocol for the successful identification, isolation, and characterization of the 4 spermatogenic cell types using cell-specific marker genes namely: melanoma antigen, family A, 4 (Magea4), heat shock protein 2 (Hspa2), cytochrome c oxidase subunit VIb polypeptide 2 (Cox6b2), transition protein 1 (Tnp1), protamine 1 (Prm1), and protamine 2 (Prm2). This was accomplished by the optimization of a short hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining protocol which was consistent with the LMD principles of maintaining acceptable morphology, within the context of preserving the quality and quantity of nucleic acids for downstream applications. Qualitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) was complemented by Western blot (WB) of the LMD samples, immunohistochemistry, and confocal localization of the corresponding proteins. The secondary aim was the extension of the validated LMD protocol, combined with qRT-PCR and protein analysis, to the cell stage-specific expression of selected stress response genes to include heat shock protein 90, alpha (cytosolic), class A member 1 (Hsp90aa1), glutathione peroxidase 4 (Gpx4), uncoupling protein 2 (mitochondrial, proton carrier Ucp2), superoxide dismutase 1 (Sod1), and superoxide dismutase 2 (Sod2). It is our hypothesis that developmental differences in the regulation of stress response genes will confer unique cellular responses by spermatogenic cell stage when exposed to male reproductive toxicants. Thus, the present study is the first to establish a modified LMD approach which was validated by cell stage-specific marker genes, and complementary protein analysis, which was further extended to the constitutive expression profiles of selected stress response genes. As a result, this LMD protocol will translate to future toxicology applications that seek to elucidate gene expression data from exposed and nonexposed cell stage-specific subpopulations.

sec.title: Animals and Organ Sampling
sec.p: Eight- to ten-week-old C57BL/6 J male mice were used as the animal model. The mice were housed, and the experimental procedures were conducted in accordance with the guidelines for the humane and ethical treatment of animals. All studies were approved by the Animal Studies Committees at Washington University School of Medicine, and the St Louis VA Medical Center.

sec.title: Tissue Preparation and H&E Staining
sec.p: Tissue preparation and staining procedures were specifically modified from earlier LMD protocols, 7,8,10,13 and optimized to isolate germ cells from the mouse testis. Experimental mice were euthanized, the testes were removed, and the tissues were processed under RNase-free conditions. Tissues were frozen within 1 minute in optimal cutting temperature compound (Tissue-Tek, Sakura Finetek, Torrance, California) and stored at −80°C for less than 1 month, if not used immediately. Cryosectioning was performed at 8-μm thickness for RNA isolation and at 12 μm for protein extraction. The sections were placed on UV sterilized 2.0 μm polyethylene naphthalate membrane slides (Leica Microsystems Deutschland, Bensheim, Germany) and were fixed for 1 minute using ice-cold acetone maintained at −15°C. The sections were then stained with CAT-hematoxylin (Biocare Medical, Concord, California) for 3 minutes, slowly rinsed twice in RNase-free distilled H2O to remove the excess hematoxylin, followed by eosin (Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, Missouri) staining for 5 seconds, and dehydrated through 70%, 95%, and 100% alcohol grades for 30 seconds each. Finally, the sections were transferred to xylene for 3 minutes and subsequently air-dried for 1 minute. By quickly moving the slides between the solutions, this short staining protocol was completed in <10 minutes to preserve tissue morphology, protect RNA integrity, and maximize RNA yield.

sec.title: Laser Microdissection
sec.p: Laser microdissection of the H&E-stained testis sections was carried out using the ×40 objective, coupled with the draw and UV cutting system of the Leica LMD 6000 (Leica Microsystems). Cell-specific labels for spermatogonia ([SG] group I), spermatocytes ([SC] group II), round and condensing spermatids (group III), elongated and condensed spermatids inclusive of luminal spermatozoa (group IV), and Leydig cells were applied to the cross sections of seminiferous tubule (see Table 1). Corresponding stage-specific labels were applied to the microdissected cell collecting tubes which held 50 μL of extraction buffer (Arcturus, Life Technologies, Foster City, California). Considering the complexity of the seminiferous epithelium, the cell types were not microdissected as either circular zones, or circumferential seminiferous tubule cross sections as described in earlier studies. 7,8 Instead the discrete cell types were dissected as clusters based upon cell morphology, size, density, and positional alignment within the seminiferous epithelium. To minimize Sertoli cell contamination, cuts were made at 90° angles to the lumen of the seminiferous tubule from an area of approximately 50 000 μm 2 . Laser microdissection was completed within 1 hour and processed on the day of capture. The entire protocol from tissue collection through RNA quantitation required about 3 hours.

caption.p: Testicular Cell Types and Specific Marker Genes.

tr.td: Elongated and condensed spermatids and luminal sperm (ESP)

sec.title: Reverse Transcriptase PCR and qRT-PCR Analysis
RNA isolation, cDNA synthesis, and RT-PCR
sec.p:
Total RNA was isolated from the LMD groups using PicoPure according to the manufacturer’s directions (Arcturus # PN: KIT0204). The quality and integrity of RNA were validated by Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer RNA 6000 Pico kit and Nanodrop. The RNA samples with 260/280 ratios ≥1.8 were used for further analysis. Briefly, RT was performed in a final volume of 20 μL with 50 ng total RNA, 10× RT buffer, 25× deoxyribonucleotide triphosphate mix (100 mmol/L), 10× RT random primers, MultiScribe Reverse Transcriptase (Applied Biosystems, Inc, Foster city, California), and nuclease-free H2O at in a thermal-cycler at 25, 37, and 85°C for 10 minutes, 2 hours, and 5 minutes, respectively. Semiquantitative RT-PCR using 200 ng of total RNA from each sample was reverse transcribed and amplified by 35 cycles using gene-specific primers for Sox9, 14 3β-Hsd, 15
Irs1, 16 and β-actin (see Table 2) by LA Taq DNA polymerase (TAKARA Biotech, Mountain View, California).

tr.td: F: 5′-CAA GAC TCT GGG CAA GCT C-3′
R: 5′-GGG CTG GTA CTT GTA ATC GG-3′
F: 5′-AGC TGC CCC TGA TCT TTT C-3′
R: 5′-GTC TGT CCT TCC CAG TGA TTG-3′
F: 5′-ATG GGA AGC CAT GGA CAA ATG GAG-3′
R: 5′-ATG TAG TCA CCT GTG CAA GGC AAG-3′
F: 5′-ACC TTC TAC AAT GAG CTG CG-3′
R: 5′-CTG GAT GGC TAC GTA CAT GG-3

sec.title: Real-time PCR analysis
sec.p: Relative quantification of gene expression was performed using TaqMan gene expression assays (Applied Biosystems) by qRT-PCR following MIQE guidelines 17 with the ABI 7500 Fast (Applied Biosystems). The cell stage-specific marker genes Magea4, Hspa2, Cox6b2, Tnp1, Prm1, Prm2 and the selected stress response genes Hsp90aa1, Gpx4, Ucp2, Sod1 and Sod2 along with their respective TaqMan probe ID and amplicon size are shown in Table 3. The candidate marker genes were selected based upon species conservation; differential expression across germ cell developmental stages, independent verification using established literature, and the Mammalian Reproductive Genetics (MRG) Database. 18 Each candidate gene, no template control, positive control, and the endogenous reference gene, β-actin 19,20 were analyzed across all 4 germ cell stages, using equal amounts of input template. Standard curve analysis was performed for all target genes and β-actin using serial dilutions of complementary DNA (cDNA) prepared from adult mouse whole testis (Agilent) to confirm amplification efficiencies, which ranged between 95% and 100%. Target gene expression was determined from the mean normalized expression that was calculated based on the mean threshold cycle (C T) of β-actin, referred to as the ΔC T, which was used to adjust differences among the samples. The ΔΔC T of the genes of interest was calculated by subtracting the ΔC T of group I (SG) from the ΔC T of all other groups. The total cDNA from the germ cells was amplified via 100 nmol/L of gene-specific primers and the TaqMan probe mix for 40 cycles of qRT-PCR using 95°C for 20 seconds for the initial denaturation followed by 40 cycles at 95°C, and 60°C for 3 and 30 seconds, respectively. Gene expression data, among the 4 germ cell groups, were analyzed using 2−ΔΔCT which reflected the relative differences in gene expression of the target genes expressed as fold changes. 21

caption.p: TaqMan Assays Used for qRT-PCR Analysis.

tr.td: Cytochrome c oxidase subunit VIb polypeptide-2 (Cox6b2, NM_183405)

sec.title: Immunohistochemistry and immunolocalization
sec.p: Paraffin sections (5-μm thick) of Bouins fixed and processed testes were used for immunohistochemistry and immunolocalization. In brief, the sections were deparaffinized, rehydrated and antigen unmasking was carried out using 10 mmol/L sodium citrate (pH 6.0). Sections were blocked with 5% (w/v) nonfat dry milk powder (NFDM) in Tris-buffered saline (TBS) for 30 minutes at room temperature and incubated at 4°C overnight with specific primary antibodies. Spermatogenic cell stage-specific proteins included mouse monoclonal MAGEA4, 1:50 (SC-101223); goat polyclonal PRM2, 1:50 (SC-23104); COX6B2, 1:50 (SC-79412 [Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc, Santa Cruz, California]); rabbit polyclonal HSPA2, 1:500 (12797-1-AP [ProteinTech, Chicago, Illinois]); and TPI, 1:500 (17178-1-AP [ProteinTech, Chicago, Illinois]). Following overnight incubation, the sections were incubated with either horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-conjugated goat-anti-rabbit, goat-anti-mouse, or donkey-anti-goat secondary antibodies (1:1000; Santa Cruz Biotechnology) for 1 hour at room temperature. The slides were then washed and the color reaction carried out using the DAB kit (SK-4100 [Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, California]). The sections were subsequently counterstained with either hematoxylin or eosin, dehydrated through alcohol grades, cleansed in xylene, and mounted using cytoseal-XYL (Richard Allan Scientific, Kalamazoo, Michigan).

Sample preparation for confocal localization of selected stress response proteins was completed as described above. Overnight incubation with the primary antibodies was completed at 1:50 dilution unless otherwise stated. The primary stress response antibodies included mouse monoclonal GPX4 (SC-166120 [Santa Cruz Biotechnology]); SOD1 (SC-271014), SOD2 (SC-133254), goat polyclonal UCP2 (SC-6526), and rabbit polyclonal HSP90αα1 1:200 (MA5-14866 [Thermoscientific, Rockford, Illinois]). Following overnight incubation, the sections were incubated with Alexa Fluor 488 goat-anti-rabbit, goat-anti-mouse, or donkey-anti-goat secondary antibodies 1:400 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology; Molecular Probes, Inc, Eugene, Oregon) for 1 hour, and counterstained with TO-PRO-3 iodide dye 1:500 (Molecular Probes) for 5 minutes. Fluorescence was visualized using confocal microscopy (Nikon Eclipse E800; Nikon Corp, Tokyo, Japan). Negative controls, without primary antibodies, were utilized to confirm nonspecific reactions.

sec.title: Western blot analysis of LMD samples
Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Data are expressed as the mean of 4 independent experiments (n = 4) each assayed in duplicate and represented as mean ± SE. The qRT-PCR data were analyzed using 1-way analysis of variance ([ANOVA] nonparametric) followed by Tukey multiple comparison test with 95% confidence intervals using Prism 5.0d (GraphPad, La Jolla) and a P value less than .05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Tissue Morphology, LMD, and qRT-PCR Analysis
sec.p: Our short LMD protocol using the modified H&E staining allowed the capture of 4 groups of spermatogenic cells from 8-μm thick frozen sections of the seminiferous epithelium as depicted in Figure 1. This short staining protocol not only preserved the morphology but also maintained the integrity of the isolated RNA with high yield of RNA. Laser microdissection yielded ∼200 to 400 ng of cell stage-specific RNA with a 260/280 ratio of ≥1.8. Prior to qRT-PCR, the purity of captured cell types was validated by semiquantitative RT-PCR using gene-specific primers of Sox9, 3β-Hsd, and Irs1 to assess for Sertoli cell, Leydig cell, and peritubular myoid cell contamination, respectively. Reverse transcriptase PCR revealed a faint Sox9 signal in SG and SCs with an intense Sox9 signal in the total testicular RNA. In comparison, 3β-Hsd- and Irs1-specific bands were detected only in total testicular RNA. A uniform intense signal for β-actin was detected in all the samples amplified (Figure 2).

caption.p: Representative diagram of laser capture microdissection (LMD) of hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained paraffin and cryosections of the mouse seminiferous epithelium (stages VII-XI). The panel depicts the H&E stained Bouins fixed paraffin section (A), unmarked cryosection (B), precut cryosection with demarcated germ cells (C), and postcut epithelium (D). Spermatogonia (SG, red); spermatocytes (SC, green); round and condensing spermatids (CSP, blue); elongated and condensed spermatids (ESP, orange) are marked separately. Bar scale = 50 μm.

Validation of germ cell microdissection by semiquantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Equal square micrometers (μm2) area of the seminiferous epithelium representing isolated cell populations and whole testis (SG: spermatogonia; SC: spermatocytes; CSP: condensing spermatids; ESP: elongated spermatids; TR: whole testis) were RNA isolated and reverse transcribed (200 ng RNA). Equal amount of complementary DNA (cDNA) was amplified using gene-specific primers of Sox9, 3β-Hsd1, Irs1, and β-actin (Table 2). A faint signal for Sox9 in SG and SC and an intense band in whole testis and 3β-Hsd1- and Irs1-specific products are seen only in whole testis. No bands were seen in negative controls in which either reverse transcriptase or the cDNA template was omitted (not shown). A 170-bp β-actin messenger RNA (mRNA) amplified served as the internal control.

sec.title: Relative Expression of Candidate Genes
sec.p: Gene expression fold changes were calculated using relative quantitation 2−ΔΔCT. The relative fold change for each group was calculated using the level in SG (group I) as one. Magea4 mRNA was maximally expressed (∼2-fold) in SG (group I), was significantly higher than in SCs, and was more than 7- and 3-fold greater than group III and group IV spermatids, respectively (Figure 3A). Figure 3B demonstrated that the Hspa2 expression was comparatively higher (∼1.7-fold) in SCs (group II) than SG (group I); and ∼2.5-fold greater when compared to round and condensing spermatids (group III), elongated and condensed spermatids, and luminal spermatozoa (group IV). The expression level of the testis-specific Cox6b2 was similar to Hspa2 and was higher in SCs (group II) compared with elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV); and ∼0.8-fold, and ∼3-fold greater than SG (group I) and round and condensing spermatids (group III [Figure 3C]). Among the candidate genes of the postmeiotic haploid spermatids, Tnp1 expression was ∼3.0-fold higher in the round and condensing spermatids (group III) than in the elongated and condensed spermatids, or luminal spermatozoa (group IV); with the expression levels either negligible or undetected in SCs or SG (Figure 3D). As seen in Figure 3E, Prm1 expression paralleled Tnp1 expression and was ∼2.6-fold higher in the round and condensing spermatids (group III), than in the elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV). Conversely, Prm2 expression was slightly higher in round and condensing spermatids (group III) compared with elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV), though the differences were not statistically significant (P < .09 [Figure 3F]).

caption.p: A-F, Germ cell marker genes in the mouse testis exhibit cell-specific increase in mRNA expression. Qualitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) analysis was used to assess the cell-specific gene expression of the laser microdissection (LMD) samples. The qRT-PCR results were normalized against the reference gene, β-actin and converted to relative (mean) fold difference of messenger RNA (mRNA) expression of the target genes Magea4, Hspa2, Cox6b2, Tnp1, Prm1, and Prm2 in spermatogonia (group I; SG, square box bars), spermatocytes (group II; SC, brick bars), round and condensing spermatids (group III; CSP, horizontal line bars) and condensed and elongated spermatids (group IV; ESP, vertical line bars). Expression levels were determined as described in the Material and Methods sections, and the relative ratio in each cell type was calculated setting the mRNA level in SG as one. Data are expressed as the mean of 4 independent experiments, each assayed in duplicate ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Statistical significance was determined using 1-way analysis of variance ([ANOVA] nonparametric) followed by Tukey multiple comparison test with 95% confidence intervals. *P < .05 (significant), **P < .01 (highly significant); and ***P < .001 (extremely significant).

sec.title: Expression Profile of Stress Response Genes
sec.p: Based on the expression profiles of the cell-specific marker genes, qRT-PCR analysis was carried out to determine the expression levels of selected stress response genes. As seen in Figure 4A, the Hsp90aa1 mRNA level was similar to Hspa2; and was higher in SCs than SG, and almost nonexistent in the postmeiotic spermatids. In the case of Gpx4, mRNA was present in pachytene SCs with continued expression throughout spermiogenesis; but undetected in SG (∼3.0-fold, Figure 4B). This expression pattern demonstrated that the mRNA appeared in the later stages of SCs, reached a peak in round and condensing spermatids (group III), and then began to decline in the elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV). Concomitant with the structural changes as depicted in Figure 4C, Ucp2 expression was observed to be ∼2.0-fold higher in SG than SCs (group II), along with its near absence in group III and IV spermatids. As shown in Figure 4D, the cytoplasmic copper–zinc SOD gene, Sod1 exhibited invariable expression across the 4-designated groups of germ cells under normal conditions, with slight elevation in the postmeiotic spermatids. Figure 4E demonstrates significant Sod2 expression in SCs (group II) when compared with group III (∼8-fold) and group IV spermatids (∼6-fold). However, there was no significant difference (∼0.8-fold) between SCs and SG.

caption.p: A-E, Characterization of oxidative stress-associated genes Hsp90aa1, Gpx4, Ucp2, Sod1, and Sod2 transcription level among germ cells. Qualitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) analysis was used to assess the germ cell-specific gene expression of the microdissected samples. The qRT-PCR results were normalized against the reference gene, β-actin and converted to relative (mean) fold difference of messenger RNA (mRNA) expression of the target genes in spermatogonia (group I; SG, square box bars), spermatocytes (group II; SC, brick bars), round and condensing spermatids (group III; CSP, horizontal line bars), and condensed and elongated spermatids (group IV; ESP, vertical line bars). Expression levels were determined as indicated in Figure 3 and the relative ratio in each cell type was calculated setting the mRNA level in SG as one. Data are expressed as the mean of 4 independent experiments, each assayed in duplicate ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Statistical significance was determined using 1-way analysis of variance ([ANOVA] nonparametric) followed by Tukey multiple comparison test with 95% confidence intervals. *P < .05 (significant), **P < .01 (highly significant); and ***P < .001 (extremely significant).

sec.title: Immunolocalization of Germ Cell Marker Proteins
sec.p: Immunohistochemical studies identified those cells expressing MAGEA4, HSPA2, COX6B2, TP1, and PRM2 proteins in the mouse testis (Figure 5). MAGEA4-specific staining was confined to the cells of the basal zone which is located at the outer margins of the seminiferous epithelium (panel B). Under oil immersion (×100), MAGEA4 signal was present in the cytoplasm and the nucleus of SG and the smaller interspersed preleptotene SCs (panel C). Panel E demonstrated ample testis-specific HSPA2 staining in almost all stages of SCs and spermatids. Under higher magnification, HSPA2-staining was specific to SCs, and exclusive to the cytoplasm (panel F). Testis-specific COX6B2 immunoperoxidase reaction was positive in SCs. A diminished signal was noted in the cytoplasmic extensions of the Sertoli cells (panel I) and other spermatogenic stages (panel H). Intense TP1 immunostaining (panel K) was noted in the elongating spermatids and within the nucleus of condensing spermatids that maintained continued sertoli-cell contact (panel L). Positive PRM2 immunoreaction appeared in the nuclei of the late stage spermatids (panel N). Under higher magnification intense PRM2 staining emerged on the thickened and condensed nuclei of the elongated spermatids (panel O). Staining was absent in the sections probed with buffer control, preimmune serum, and secondary antibody alone (panels A, D, G, J, and M).

caption.p: Immunofluorescent localization of germ cell marker proteins MAGEA4, HSPA2, COX6B2, TP1, and PRM2 in the mouse testis. The seminiferous epithelium was probed with corresponding anti-goat or anti-mouse or anti-rabbit secondary antibodies, Alexa Fluor 488 (green fluorescence) according to their specific primary antibodies for MAGEA4 (panels A and C), HSPA2 (panels D and F), COX6B2 (panels G and I), TP1 (panels J and L), and PRM2 (panels M and O). The sections shown in the middle panel demonstrates nuclear counterstaining with TO-PRO-3 iodide (blue channel). Bar scale = 50 µm.

sec.title: Confocal Localization of Stress Response Proteins
sec.p: Confocal localization revealed a strong signal for HSP90AA1 in the cytoplasm of SCs and round spermatids but not in the elongated spermatids or Sertoli cells (Figure 6, panels A and C). The testis abundant GPX4 was concentrated exclusively in the cytoplasm of the condensing, condensed, and periluminal elongated spermatids. No fluorescence was seen in other cell types (Figure 6, panels D and F). An intense fluorescent signal for mitochondrial UCP2 was seen exclusively in the cytoplasm overlaying the elongating and condensing sperm head at the various seminiferous epithelium stages (Figure 6, panels G and I). Similar to MAGEA4, SOD1 was exclusively localized at the cytoplasm of SG (Figure 6, panels J and L). In comparison, mitochondrial SOD2 exhibited an intense and typical punctuate fluorescence only in the cytoplasm of SG, primary SCs, and secondary SCs (Figure 6, panels M and O). Immunostaining specificity was demonstrated by the absence of fluorescent signal on sections incubated with secondary antibody alone (negative control, data not shown).

caption.p: Confocal visualization of HSP90AA1, GPX4, UCP2, SOD1, and SOD2 localization in the testis. As detailed for immunofluorescence, the seminiferous epithelium was localized with corresponding anti-goat or anti-mouse or anti-rabbit secondary antibodies, Alexa Fluor 488 (green fluorescence) according to their specific primary antibodies for HSP90AA1 (panels A and C), GPX4 (panels D and F), UCP2 (panels G and I), SOD1 (panels J and L), and SOD2 (panels M and O). The sections shown in the middle panel demonstrates nuclear counterstaining with TO-PRO-3 iodide (blue channel). Bar scale = 50 µm.

sec.title: Western Blot Analysis of LMD Samples
sec.p: Western blot was carried out using pooled cell stage-specific LMD isolated proteins and was extracted from equal micrometer square areas of the frozen testis cross sections. As seen in Figure 7, protein-specific bands of marker proteins were detected in their respective germ cell types. A ∼35 kDa molecular weight protein was detected in lane Sg (SG) for MAGEA4 (Figure 7 panel A) when probed with anti-MAGEA4 antibody. Anti-HSPA2 antibody detected a 70 kDa protein in lane Sc (SC), with a slightly lighter HSPA2 band in lane Spr (spermatids [Figure 7 panel B]). Panel C was probed with anti-COX6B2 and demonstrated an 11 kDa protein band in lane Sg (SG) and Sc (SCs) with a lighter COX6B2 signal in lane Lc (Leydig cells). Panel D was probed with anti-PRM2 and an 18 kDa band was detected for PRM2 in lane Spr (spermatids). Anti-β-tubulin antibody detected β-tubulin as a 55-kDa protein band in all lanes (blot E).

caption.p: Detection of MAGEA4, HSPA2, COX6B2, and PRM2 in laser captured samples from the mouse testis by Western blot analysis. Equal square micrometer (μm2) area of the seminiferous epithelium representing individual cell populations (Sg: spermatogonia; Sc: spermatocytes; Spr: spermatids; LC: Leydig cells) was microdissected and proteins extracted were probed with specific primary antibodies for MAGEA4 (panel A), HSPA2 (panel B), COX6B2 (panel C), and PRM2 (D). Equal loading of protein is shown in the panel E probed with anti-β-tubulin antibody.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Laser microdissection was recently developed as a cell-purification technique that facilitates the isolation of individual cell populations from complex tissues. However, testes architecture coupled with several methodological barriers present distinct challenges when working with complex tissues such as the testis. The quantity of RNA from LMD samples is typically low (about 5-20 pg/cell) and fragmented. 21 Previous reports demonstrated that RNA extraction from Stieve, GR fixative and formalin fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue resulted in low yield and poor quality of RNA. 13 Likewise, past studies advocated the staining of LMD sections with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole nuclear stain, peanut agglutinin lectin, methylene blue, or Mayer hematoxylin. 15,22 However, our initial attempts at performing LMD with these dyes proved unsuccessful and resulted in either poor tissue morphology or poor capture success due to bleaching and compromised tissue integrity. Immunostaining techniques using specific marker proteins as suggested by prior work 23 were not employed in this study. The prolonged exposure to aqueous solutions would be expected to compromise tissue morphology and nucleic acid integrity. However, our LMD protocol was designed to maximize and preserve the quantity and integrity of the nucleic acids; while securing acceptable tissue morphology to ensure LMD success. We modified the conventional H&E staining to a shorter protocol of <10 minutes duration using CAT-hematoxylin with a brief exposure to aqueous solutions and using xylene as the final dehydrant. This modified H&E staining maintained the integrity and morphology of the seminiferous epithelium while protecting the quality and quantity of RNA. RNA quantity per cell stage ranged between ∼200 and 400 ng from approximately 50 000 μm 2 of the seminiferous epithelium, with a 260/280 ratio of ≥1.8. Because of the variability of size and ploidy of the differentiating male gametes, equal square micrometer (μm 2 ) areas of the seminiferous epithelium were dissected by cell stage, instead of using cell count as a strategy for LMD normalization. 21

During spermatogenesis, multiple cell stages maintain direct sertoli cell contact. Sertoli cells have an enormous surface area that allows them to sustain a vast number of developing germ cells at a Sertoli-to-germ cell ratio of ∼1:50 in the adult rat testis. 24 Nevertheless, the intricate sertoli cell and germ cell associations make it difficult to isolate pure germ cell subpopulations. Past work either dissected entire cross sections, 7 or described zonal dissection of the seminiferous tubules known to be populated by the target cell populations. 8 Using the Acturus PIXEL LCM, Sluka et al 7 captured entire cross sections of rat seminiferous tubules to result in aggregate cellular signals from the complex cell population. Cells captured would have included leydig cells, myoid cells, sertoli cells, and male germ cells in various stages of development. The Arcturus manual Pixel, the automated Arcturus AutoPix, and the Biorad Clonis are pure IR systems that do not allow single cell LMD. In comparison, the UV systems (Leica LMD 6000 and 7000, the Zeiss PALM, and Molecular Machines CellCut) allow single cell dissection, making the UV system ideal for dissecting differentiating male gametes. While single cell LMD would certainly produce pure germ cell populations, it would also greatly increase the time spent in LMD with the potential to compromise the integrity of RNA. As previously noted, regional zones of the seminiferous tubules known to be populated by the selected cell stages (basal, mid section, and luminal) were collected 8 rather than discrete germ cell subpopulations. However, the cytoplasmic bridges which connect the differentiating cell stages, suggested cluster LMD as a viable option to isolate pure cell subpopulations, maximize the quality and quantity of nucleic acids, and minimize somatic cell contamination. Semiquantitative RT-PCR detected minimal Sox9 expression in SG and SCs which suggested limited Sertoli cell contamination, while the absence of Sox9 in the subsequent cell stages supported the absence of Sertoli cell contamination. For these reasons the draw and cut feature of the Leica MLD 6000, was the ideal platform for cluster LMD which enhanced our capacity to isolate specific germ cell populations within the construct of maximal RNA quantity, reduced time, and the protection of RNA integrity. Technologies such as flow cytometry with immunostaining may be well suited to the segregation of cells in suspension. However, these technologies disrupt adherent cells and profoundly alter gene expression. 9 In addition, methods such as sedimentation or percoll gradients can purify only 1 meiotic cell type at a time but with few exceptions fail to yield sufficient purity of cell subpopulations. 25 As a result, LMD has been noted to be the only technology that allows the isolation of cell subpopulations from complex tissues without disturbing the cell’s bimolecular signature. 9

Laser microdissection was previously employed in the study of gene expression during mammalian spermatogenesis. 26,7,8 However, this is the first time that LMD, followed by qRT-PCR, immunolocalization, and WB was applied to the characterization of male germ cells at different stages of development using cell stage-specific marker genes at both the mRNA and protein levels, as a method of validating LMD cell stage-specific success. Qualitative RT-PCR using relative quantitation (2−ΔΔCT), normalized to β-actin and the calibrator sample (group I SG), revealed developmental differences in the expression of Magea4, Hspa2, Cox6b2, Tnp1, Prm1, and Prm2 during the stages of spermatogenesis which was consistent with the functional roles and conformed to the published data. The purity of the group I sample for SG was validated by the differential expression of the cancer/testis gene, Magea4 which was found to be significantly higher in SG, and to a lesser extent in SCs than in any of the other cell types or stages. This was complemented by immunolocalization of MAGEA4 on SG in the basal compartment of the seminiferous epithelium. The unique expression pattern of Magea4 in SG and its abundant activation in several solid tumors 27,28 implicate Magea4 in the maintenance of normal SG stem cells and cancer cell proliferation. HSPA2 is required for desynapsis of synaptonemal complex 29 and is highly expressed in meiotic SCs. 30 This current study reported maximal Hspa2 mRNA expression in SCs which was subsequently supported by immunolocalization. HSPA2 staining was absent in SG. However, intense HSPA2 staining was present in SCs with a gradual decline in spermatids which is consistent with prior published data. 31,32 Cox6b2 expression corresponded to Hspa2 mRNA. 33 Nevertheless the varying protein expression by WB and immunolocalization may represent nonspecific staining. Qualitative RT-PCR analyses of Tnp1, Prm1, and Prm2 demonstrated mRNA expression specific to round and condensing spermatids (group III), and elongated and condensed spermatids (group IV). Interestingly, the maximal Prm2 expression appeared in both the condensing (group III) and elongated (group IV) spermatids. While this supported the overlapping nature of these nucleoproteins, 34 –36 it also suggested the remote possibility that this LMD sample of group IV spermatids may have been overpopulated with early steps of condensing spermatids. TP1 and PRM2 immunostaining and WB supported earlier reports 35,36 and reiterated the above observations. Transition proteins 1 and 2 act as intermediate DNA binding proteins during the histone–protamine exchange, 37 whereby protamines replace nuclear histones during spermatozoa reorganization. Protamines contain numerous cysteine residues that stabilize the chromatin structure and protect the DNA from reactive oxygen species (ROS). 38

In accordance with prior published data of differential spermatogenic cell stage sensitivities to physical or chemical agents, 39 our hypothesis suggests that the constitutive expression of stress response genes will differ by cell stage to create stage-specific vulnerabilities to reproductive toxicants. To establish a foundation for this hypothesis, the current LMD protocol was combined with qRT-PCR and protein analysis to establish baseline cell stage-specific expression patterns of the selected stress response genes. Oxidative stress that disrupts testicular steroidogenesis 40 and differentiation of the germinal epithelium 39 is a critical factor in the etiology of male infertility. 41 The highly inducible testicular Hsp90aa1
42 is associated with tumor progression, 43 cell signaling, and regulation. Hsp90aa1 has attracted greater attention in mammalian spermatogenesis owing to the fact that Hsp90aa1 mutant male mice were reportedly sterile and azoospermic. 42 Consistent with our hypothesis regarding the potential stage-specific expression of stress response genes, the current study reveals that the level of Hsp90aa1 mRNA was higher in SCs as reported by prior published data. 39 However, this is the first report of Hspa2 and Cox6b2 expression patterns that were similar to Hsp90αα1. These observations concur with previous findings by immunoelectron microscopy 44 and mutation studies. 42 Similar to Hspa2, the higher level of Hsp90aa1 in SCs suggests that the protein is indispensable for synaptonemal complex disassembly and/or progression through the pachytene checkpoint. Hsp90aa1 is also a member of a highly conserved pathway to protect cells from physical and chemical stress. 45 Gpx4 exhibits the highest level of expression and activity in the testis 46 along with its mRNA in a stage-specific manner. 47 The increased distribution of Gpx4 mRNA and the confocal localization of the corresponding protein in the late round and condensing spermatids (group III) in this study are consistent with earlier observations. The cell-specific expression of Gpx4 signifies its importance as an antioxidant as well as its pivotal role in male fertility. 48,49

UCP2 is predominantly expressed in the testis and is essential in the prevention of the production of excess ROS and mitochondrial membrane hyperpolarization. 50 –52 Consistent with prior work 53 our study demonstrated the maximal Ucp2 expression in SG (C T 25-30), and exclusive UCP2 protein localization to the elongated spermatids. Among the various proteins protecting the male germ cells against ROS, SOD1, and SOD2 are among the most important antioxidant scavengers. Lasso and colleagues 54 reported that the partial loss of SOD1 confers enhanced susceptibility to O2 toxicity and renders sperm immotile. Sod1 encodes 3 different splice variants in the mouse testis. The somatic Sod1 isoform is found in the premeiotic male germ cells and the 2 postmeiotic variants predominate during spermiogenesis. 55 With the exception of the marginal increase in Sod1 expression in spermatids, our work documented Sod1 in all cell stages. Sod2 expression was significantly higher in SCs and paralleled SOD2 protein localization. This finding was consistent with prior reports that found SOD2 to be negligible or absent in spermatids. 56 Taken together, these findings suggest that the antioxidant defense system has been vividly demarcated between the premeiotic and postmeiotic germ cells in the testis.

In summary, the present study comprehensively demonstrated a short LMD protocol, combined with qRT-PCR, and confocal microscopy to characterize the differentiating male gametes via stage-specific marker genes. Furthermore, it provided a window into the cell stage-specific constitutive expression of selected stress response genes by cell stage. The understanding of gene expression at the level of transcription, translation and posttranslational modifications is essential to fully unravel its functional significance under varied biological conditions. As a result, a methodological foundation was established to elicit the cell stage-specific effects of male reproductive toxicants on the differentiating male gametes.
